Disturbed sleep, fatigue, anxiety and depression in myocardial
infarction patients
Ingvor Johansson a , Björn W. Karlson b , Gunne Grankvist c , Eva Brink d,e, ⁎
a Department of Internal Medicine, NU Hospital group, Sweden
b Astra Zeneca R&D, Mölndal, Sweden
c Department of Social and Behavioural Studies, University West, Sweden
d Department of Nursing, Health and Culture, University West, Sweden
e Institute of Health and Care Sciences, The Sahlgrenska Academy at University of Gothenburg, Sweden
Received 17 April 2009; received in revised form 4 November 2009; accepted 15 December 2009
Available online 13 January 2010
Abstract
Background: Disturbed sleep has been linked to increased morbidity, mortality and depression and worsened health-related quality of life in
patients with chronic illness. Few studies of readjustment after coronary artery disease have explicitly focused on sleep disturbance.
Aim: To explore associations between disturbed sleep, fatigue, anxiety and depression, and to assess to what extent fatigue four months post-
MI could be explained.
Method: The sample included 204 consecutive patients, ≤ 80 years of age who answered questionnaires about disturbed sleep, fatigue,
anxiety and depression four months after MI.
Results: The variables anxiety, depression and disturbed sleep were all associated with fatigue. The regression model accounted for 46% of
the variance in fatigue with depression and disturbed sleep as predictors. Infarct size measured by conventional biochemical markers, left
ventricle ejection fraction and history of previous MI were not correlated with disturbed sleep, fatigue, anxiety or depression.
Conclusions: From knowledge about associations between disturbed sleep, fatigue, anxiety and depression after MI, cardiac nurses could be
trained to observe such symptoms. Optimal care for sleep disturbance may include actions to reduce anxiety and depression as well as self-
care advices about sleep hygiene in order to improve sleep quality and reduce fatigue.

Keywords: Anxiety; Depression; Disturbed sleep; Fatigue; Myocardial infarction

1. Introduction
Fatigue has been found to be a significant health
complaint in myocardial infarction (MI) patients [1–4], as
well as something that is difficult to cope with [5]. A wide
range of definitions are found in the literature. Fatigue is a
multidimensional construct with components of general,
physical, and mental fatigue, as well as reduced activity and
motivation [6]. Fatigue can be distinguished from tiredness
by defining a continuum along which fatigue is a state
existing anywhere between the two poles tiredness and
exhaustion [7]. High rates of depression [8–10] and anxiety
[10,11] have been found among patients who have suffered
an MI. Fatigue and depression may be different expressions
of the same phenomenon [12,13], or they may tend to
overlap, as fatigue is a key symptom of depression [14,15].
Nevertheless, fatigue is sometimes experienced by myocar-
dial infarction patients without coexisting depression [3],
and therefore measures of physical components of fatigue

Adaptation after MI entails adjustment to illness con-
sequences [16,17], management of behavioural and lifestyle
changes [18,19] and a desire to return to normal [20].
Few studies of adaptation after MI have explicitly focused
on fatigue and sleep disturbance. Sleep disturbance refers to
an imbalance of sleep and wakefulness during a night of
sleep [21–23]. The mean sleep time for an adult, up to
64 years of age, is about 7.5 h [24,25]. One study conducted
one year after percutaneous transluminal coronary angio-
plasty (PTCA) showed that physical tiredness/fatigue was
the greatest consequence of disturbed sleep [26]. A recent
interview study of patients with coronary artery disease
(CAD) revealed that personal lifestyle was reflected in sleep
behaviour, showing that maintaining a balance between
sleep, rest and activities resulted in better sleep quality [27].
Women report a higher prevalence of sleep disturbances
[23–25,28,29]. This is in line with results from studies on
women with CAD, who report sleep disturbances more
frequently than men do [30,31]. Sleeplessness behaviour,
depressed mood and female gender were associated with poor
sleep quality in CAD patients [32].
Disturbed sleep has been linked to increased morbidity
and mortality [33–35], depression [36,37], and worsened
health-related quality of life in patients with chronic illness
[38]. Poor prognosis has been described in MI or CAD
patients who have poor sleep quality [14], and there is an
increased risk for CAD in persons with disturbed sleep [39].
The negative effects of sleep disturbance on health,
together with frequent experiences of mental distress and
fatigue after MI, make it important to further explore this
field. Therefore, the present study had two primary aims: 1.
to explore associations between disturbed sleep, fatigue,
anxiety and depression four months after MI, and 2. to assess
to what extent fatigue four months post-MI could be
explained by disturbed sleep, anxiety and depression.
2. Methods
2.1. Subjects and procedures
The present study included MI patients, ≤80 years of age,
who had been admitted to the coronary care unit in two
Swedish hospital from October 2005 to September 2006, and
who participated in a longitudinal follow-up study of
readjustment one week and four months after MI. Excluded
were patients with other severe diseases and/or a greatly
limited life expectancy (e.g., due to cancer), patients who
were not able to participate (e.g., due to stroke and dementia
disorders) and patients who could not speak Swedish
fluently. Of the 236 invited patients, 204 (144 men, 60
women) agreed to participate (response rate 87%). Demo-
graphic and medical data were obtained from hospital charts
and from a questionnaire finalized during the first week in
hospital. The demographic data covered age, gender and
living alone or together. The medical data covered previous
diagnosis (hypertension, hyperlipedemia, angina pectoris,
previous MI, congestive heart failure, diabetes mellitus, and
left ventricular ejection fraction) and acute treatment (beta-
blocker medication, percutaneous coronary intervention
(PCI), coronary artery bypass graft surgery (CABG) and
thrombolysis. Infarct size was measured using the biochem-
ical marker Troponin I (TNI). Left ventricular ejection
fraction was measured using transthoracic echocardiography
and is presented in percent.
Four months after the MI, the patients answered
questionnaires about sleep disturbance, fatigue, anxiety and
depression.
The project was approved by the Research Ethics
Committee at the University of Gothenburg. The informants
gave their informed written consent to participate, and the
investigation conforms to the principles outlined in the
Declaration of Helsinki [40].
2.2. Questionnaires
2.2.1. Disturbed sleep
Initially, nine questions regarding sleep disturbance,
previously used as separate items in studies at Sahlgrenska
University Hospital, Sweden e.g., [41], and also found to be
included in the Karolinska Sleep Questionnaire (KSQ) [42],
were analysed. The nine items were tested for reliability to
form a scale. The inter-item correlations for all items were
not fully satisfactory. Therefore, in the first step, two of them
were excluded due to doubtful content (nightmares and
involuntary sleep episodes during day-time). The Cronbach
alpha coefficient for the scale with seven items was 0.80. In
the second step, we excluded two more items with low inter-
item correlations (difficulty waking and taking sleeping
pills). Cronbach's alpha coefficient increased to 0.83 and the
inter-item correlations were good and indicated that the
remaining five items could be summed to form a scale about
sleep disturbance after MI. The final 5 items included in the
questionnaire were related to disturbed or troubled sleep,
difficulties initiating sleep, repeated nocturnal awakenings
associated with difficulties returning to sleep, a feeling of
non-refreshing sleep upon awakening, and premature
awakening from sleep. Each question was answered using
a 6-point scale with scores from never (1) to always (6)
(range 5–30).
2.2.2. Fatigue
Fatigue was measured using the Somatic Health Com-
plaints Questionnaire (SHCQ). This questionnaire addresses
13 health issues concerning common health problems in
cardiac patients [43]. In the present study, the subscale
fatigue, consisting of the four items general fatigue,
weakness, lack of energy and dizziness, was used. Each
question was answered using a 6-point scale with scores
from never (1) to always (6) (range 4–24). The Cronbach's
alpha coefficient in the present sample was 0.87.

2.2.3. Anxiety and depression
The Hospital-Anxiety Depression Scale (HAD) is a 14-item
questionnaire comprising two scales, one for anxiety (seven
questions) and one for depression (seven questions). All items
were scored on a 4-point scale from low anxiety/depression (0)
to high anxiety/depression (3) [44]. The HAD Scale was
developed for measuring mental distress in patients with
physical illness and has been found to be a reliable instrument
for detecting severity of emotional distress, with Cronbach's
alpha between 0.80 and 0.93 [45]. On either the anxiety or
depression subscale, a score of 7 or less is considered normal, a
score of 8–10 is considered to indicate possible and 11 or
higher to indicate probable psychological distress.
2.3. Statistical analyses
The Statistical Package for the Social Sciences (SPSS) 15.0
was used. Descriptive statistics were calculated: mean (m) and
standard deviations (SD). Pearson's correlation coefficients (r)
were used to explore associations between variables. Gender
differences were tested using independent sample t-tests. To
identify variables that best predicted fatigue in myocardial
infarction patients, a multiple regression model was used with
sleep disturbance, anxiety, depression, gender and age as
independent variables. A p-value b 0.05 was considered sta-
tistically significant.
3. Results
3.1. Demographic data
Table 1 shows the characteristics of the participating
patients, including medical information. The mean age was
64 years (SD = 10, range 31–80) and 30% were women. One
fourth of the sample had a diagnosis of at least one previous
MI. Only 7% suffered from congestive heart failure, and
nearly one fourth were hyperlipidemic. The acute treatment
included CABG in 7% and PCI in 70% of the sample.
3.2. Disturbed sleep
Means, SDs and ranges for disturbed sleep measured as
described above are displayed in Table 2. The theoretical ranges
of scale scores were well covered by the observed scores for all
four scales. A gender difference was identified; women
reported more disturbed sleep (p b 0.05). Difficulties falling
asleep during the past week were reported by 21% of the
individuals four months after the MI. A feeling of non-
refreshing sleep upon awakening was the most common sleep
complaint (Table 3). Of all patients, 55% reported sleep
disturbance sometimes to always, 45% reported almost no sleep
disturbance at all, and 79% did not use any sleep medication.
3.3. Fatigue
One third of the MI patients reported fatigue often to
always (summed SHCQ scale scores between 13 and 24),
one third reported fatigue sometimes, and 35% experienced
hardly any fatigue at all. No difference between women and
men was identified (Table 2).
3.4. Anxiety and depression
According to the HAD scale, one fourth of the MI patients
scored possible or probable anxiety, and 20% scored
possible or probable depression. Regarding anxiety a
difference between women and men was identified (Table 2).

previous MI were not significantly correlated with disturbed
sleep, fatigue, anxiety or depression. The variables disturbed
sleep, anxiety and depression were all associated with fatigue
(Table 4).
To further explore these associations, a regression model
was analysed with fatigue as the dependent variable and
disturbed sleep, anxiety and depression as independent
variables, controlling for age and gender. The regression
model accounted for 46% of the variance in fatigue, with
depression and disturbed sleep as strong predictors.
Additionally, age, but not gender, was related to fatigue
(Table 5).
4. Discussion
Four months after the acute heart attack, one third of the
patients reported fatigue sometimes too often. Also, around
20% reported sleep disturbance. Medical variables such as
enzymatically estimated infarct size or left ventricular ejection
fraction were not related to the individuals' experience of
fatigue. However, our findings showing relationships between
disturbed sleep, fatigue, anxiety and depression point out that
these aspects are important in rehabilitation care, especially
with aging people. In a multiple regression model analysis, it
was found that both depression and disturbed sleep explained a
great deal of the variance in fatigue.
Many individuals who have suffered an MI report fatigue
prior to the acute heart event [46], and many patients report
fatigue after MI [5,47,48]. The prevalence of fatigue in CAD
patients tends to be higher among women [3,32] and is linked
to increased prevalence of depression and anxiety [3,15].
Fatigue has been found to be associated with subjective sleep
quality in the general population [15] and fragmented sleep in
CAD patients [26]. Also, poor prognosis in female coronary
patients was associated with poor sleep and sleep without a
restorative function [49]. In the present study, we identified
some gender differences; women reported more anxiety and
disturbed sleep, but did not report higher rates of fatigue.
In the literature, there are several terms for an individual's
report of difficulty with sleep. Commonly used concepts are
insomnia and disturbed sleep, both including for example
difficulty falling asleep, problems with staying asleep and/or
non-restorative sleep [50,51]. Nevertheless, measures of
insomnia and disturbed sleep vary across studies, and
therefore it may be difficult to compare the results. About
18% of the general population report sleep dissatisfaction
[29,52], and this proportion is in line with that found among
the individuals who have suffered an MI in the present study
and in a former study of MI patients [2]. In the present study,
one problem associated with identifying disturbed sleep due
to the heart attack itself is that we do not know the prevalence
of impaired sleep before the MI. However, one possible
reflection is that sleep disturbance after MI may be
associated with the illness. Due to anxiety and worries
about illness consequences, insomnia problems may occur.
Physical functioning may be reduced, implying decreased
physical activity and exercise, which in turn may negatively
influence sleep quality. Also, experiences of fatigue may
lead to day-time rests or naps, which in turn may influence
the quality of night-time sleep.
To our knowledge, no previous studies have evaluated the
effects of any treatment on disturbed sleep among post-MI
patients. Individuals with insomnia are more likely to have a
major depressive illness [29]. When depression is the main
cause of sleep disturbance, anti-depressive therapy might be
required. Individuals who were distressed in the hospital
experienced lowered health-related quality of life four
months [53] and one year after MI [11], and therefore, in-
hospital identification and treatment of anxiety and depres-
sion could be of benefit to patients' prognosis. Nurses should
increase their awareness regarding anxiety, depression and
fatigue as well as regarding the impact of sleep disturbance
on health and well-being. Johansson et al. [27] concluded
that it is important to identify patients' needs, symptoms and
self-care strategies regarding impaired sleep.
4.1. Limitations
One limitation of the present study was that sleep
disturbance was not examined before MI, and thus we
cannot determine whether these problems were new and due
to illness consequences. The results only reflect the situation

four months after an MI. It might be worthwhile to perform a
prolonged follow-up for several years. Such a study could
provide the opportunity to estimate the medical risks and
morbidity resulting from sleep disturbance post-MI, and the
possible beneficial effects of a well-performed nursing inter-
vention intended to increase sleep quality. Regarding the few
identified gender differences in the present study, the small
sample size of women could have camouflaged such differ-
ences. However, to guarantee satisfactory representatively,
we performed the data collection during a period of one
year and included every consecutive patient admitted to a
rural coronary care unit with a diagnosis of an acute MI.
This procedure resulted in more male participants due to
the difference in incidence of MI between men and wom-
en ≤80 years of age.
The items used for assessing disturbed sleep in the present
study reflect a basis for insomnia symptoms that did not
include an obstructive sleep apnea (OSA) evaluation.
Coronary heart disease has been associated with OSA. A
high prevalence of OSA in patients with acute myocardial
infarction has been identified [54]. Some of the participants
in our sample may have suffered from problems with sleep
apnea causing depression, fatigue and non-restorative sleep,
while others may have experienced disturbed sleep for other
reasons. The item "a feeling of non-refreshing sleep upon
awakening" was the most common sleep complaint (reported
by 23% of the respondents), which could be a sign of OSA.
In future research, this distinction should be accounted for.
5. Conclusion
Associations between sleep disturbance, fatigue, anxiety
and depression were identified. Infarct size measured using
conventional biochemical markers, left ventricle ejection
fraction and history of previous MI were not correlated with
disturbed sleep, fatigue, anxiety or depression. Thus, psycho-
social symptoms and needs are important to recognize owing to
their influence on health and well-being. Based on knowledge
about associations between disturbed sleep, fatigue and
psychological distress such as anxiety and depression, cardiac
nurses could be trained to observe such symptoms. Optimal
care of sleep disturbance may include measures to reduce
anxiety and depression as well as self-care advice on sleep
hygiene intended to improve sleep quality and reduce fatigue.
